To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
guardians of the galaxy blue guy in prison
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
In the "Guardians of the Galaxy" film series, the blue character who is imprisoned is known as Yondu Udonta. He is a member of the Ravagers and serves as a father figure to Peter Quill (Star-Lord). In the first film, Yondu is depicted as a somewhat antagonistic character who has captured Peter Quill as a child and raised him. He is later revealed to have a more complex character, especially in "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2," where his backstory and relationship with Peter are explored further. 

In the context of the question, it is likely referring to a scene where Yondu is imprisoned, which occurs in the first film when he is trying to capture the Orb (the Power Stone) and is at odds with other characters. 

Answer:
The blue guy in prison in "Guardians of the Galaxy" is Yondu Udonta.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
guardians of the galaxy blue guy in prison
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In the "Sinestro Corps War" storyline, Superboy-Prime and Cyborg Superman escape imprisonment when the Sinestro Corps attacks Oa, killing the guards on Prime Duty. Guy, along with fellow Green Lanterns Hal Jordan and John Stewart, are captured by Parallax during battle and brought to Qward. Guy and Stewart are then held prisoner by Lyssa Drak, who forces them to relive tragedies in their lives. Hal manages to defeat Lyssa and free Guy and John from their nightmare. In the skirmish following their escape, Parallax nearly breaks Gardner\'s neck. Upon returning to their universe, they defend Earth from the entire Sinestro Corps. After helping to free Kyle from Parallax\'s possession, Parallax is split into four pieces by former Guardians Ganthet and Sayd, and placed into the power batteries of Hal, John, Guy, and Kyle. Guy is infected by the Sinestro Corps\' deadly alien virus named Despotellis, but cured by the Green Lantern Corps\' own sentient smallpox virus, Leezle Pon.\n', "Feeling depressed after a phone conversation with his family, during which his father dismisses superheroes as overly reliant on their powers, Guy attempts to spend the night fighting crime with only his natural skills. This backfires when he interrupts a police sting operation, culminating in him being arrested by his sister. While in prison, he is attacked by the Third Army, but is rescued by Green Lanterns Simon Baz and B'dg, who send the civilians to safety before crushing the Third Army and retreating to the Sea of Tranquility on the moon. Guy is angered when he discovers that the Guardians have turned against him and the Corps. Simon and B'dg dispatch him to the planet Oa. There, Guy reclaims his ring and joins Kilowog and the others reserve Corps members in their rebellion against the treacherous Guardians.\n", 'Guy Gardner is the hot-headed member of the Green Lantern Corps. He is the third human to earn a Green Lantern ring. His antics caused a K\'Vellian prisoner to go on a path of destructive rage, but thanks to Batman, the prisoner was stopped and he has Guy clean up the mess it made. He reappears in "The Eyes of Despero!" to help Batman overthrow dictator Despero. At first, he is extremely rude to Batman, constantly degrading him, but the last straw comes when he refuses to listen to Batman\'s plan; the Dark Knight punches him unconscious, and Gardner grudgingly gives his respect. He, Sinestro, and G\'nort create a Batarmor for the job upon him requesting that he come. When he sees Sinestro attempting to blow up a rogue Mogo; they do battle, with Guy winning. Guy imprisoned Sinestro in his ring at the end of the episode. In fact, in this same episode he proves to have a much stronger conscience than he originally appeared to have. He also makes a brief cameo in "Mayhem of the Music Meister!". In "Death Race to Oblivion!", it is revealed that Guy has a fear of clowns when the Joker runs him off the road in a Mongul-sanctioned race for Earth\'s survival. In "Revenge of the Reach!" Guy Gardener is one of the Green Lanterns who try to get the "suit" off of Blue Beetle\'s back. He does not like the Blue Beetle in the beginning, but at the end they become friends. He is later seen fighting against the Starro invasion of Oa alongside Kilowog, Ultra the Multi-Alien, Captain Comet and Space Ranger before succumbing to the Star Conqueror.\n', 'Communicating over the radio with Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau), a New York City Transit Authority police lieutenant, Blue demands a $1 million ransom to be delivered within one hour or he\'ll kill one hostage for every minute it is late. Green sneezes periodically, to which Garber always responds, "Gesundheit." Garber, his co-worker Lt. Rico Patrone (Jerry Stiller), and others cooperate while speculating about the hijackers\' escape plan. Garber surmises that one hijacker must be a former motorman since they were able to drive the car down the tunnel.\n', 'The Green Lantern Corps imprison Superboy-Prime inside a red Sun-Eater. The series ends with him carving an "S" into his chest with his bare hands and declaring that he has escaped from worse prisons than this.\n', "It is revealed in the Guardians of the Galaxy series that Nagan is one of the inmates left behind in the Negative Zone's Prison 42. There, he is involved in a fight with Star-Lord, who is trying to stop Blastaar and his horde from invading Earth via the closed portal in the prison.\n", 'Blair\'s leave on Akko Base in the Canewdon System is cut short, but he doesn\'t mind one bit: Zachary "Jazz" Colson, the traitor from "Wing Commander 2", has been sentenced to death, and Maverick will be escorting his prison ship. However, a distraction allows the Mandarins, a society of human traitors that Jazz belongs to, to hijack the "Bastille" and free Jazz. When he returns to the "Concordia", Blair discovers that a new squadron has arrived: the Wild Eagles, under command of Todd "Maniac" Marshall, flying the experimental "Morningstar" heavy fighters. Almost immediately the Morningstars show their problems: their jump drives don\'t work very well, forcing Blair to jump out and rescue an ejected pilot, Captain Maria "Minx" Grimaldi. She\'s very thankful for the rescue. Finally, while on patrol, Blair encounters a crippled Kilrathi "Dorkathi" transport, which surrenders. A Mandarin agent on board reveals that this freighter, the "Gamal Gan", was headed to Ayer\'s Rock, the Mandarins\' home base. This is the first indication that the Kilrathi are actively aiding the Mandarins, though the player has known for a while: one of the game\'s opening scenes shows the Emperor ordering a Mandarin to capture a Morningstar using them.\n', 'During the "Civil War II" storyline, Goliath is shown to be an inmate at the Cellar. Mad Thinker tries to recruit him during a massive prison break, but he declines. He later defeats the villains and saves several guards\' lives. For his heroic actions, Goliath is released from the Cellar on parole.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Guardians of the Galaxy" (2014) - Prisoner, cameo\n', 'A year later, Superboy-Prime sits naked in his cell and is watched over by a special cadre of Green Lanterns, including Guy Gardner, when the Guardians of the Universe discuss whether they should question him.\n']

It sets the stage for understanding the types of characters and conflicts that may arise in a prison setting within the superhero narrative.

4. **General Prison Themes**:
   - **Passage**: "During the 'Civil War II' storyline, Goliath is shown to be an inmate at the Cellar... For his heroic actions, Goliath is released from the Cellar on parole."

- **Thematic Parallels**: The themes of imprisonment, redemption, and the struggle against overwhelming odds are prevalent in both the Green Lantern and Guardians of the Galaxy narratives. **Expert Panel Discussion on "Guardians of the Galaxy Blue Guy in Prison"**

**Expert 1: Comic Book Historian**
The passages highlight various instances of imprisonment within the DC and Marvel universes, particularly focusing on characters like Guy Gardner and Superboy-Prime. Guy Gardner, a member of the Green Lantern Corps, has a complex relationship with authority and imprisonment. His experience in prison, where he is attacked by the Third Army, showcases the challenges faced by heroes even when they are incarcerated. This reflects a broader theme in comic narratives where heroes often confront their own vulnerabilities.

**Expert 2: Character Development Analyst**
From a character development perspective, Guy Gardner's imprisonment serves as a critical turning point. His anger towards the Guardians and subsequent rebellion against them illustrates his growth from a hot-headed individual to a more nuanced character who questions authority. This transformation is essential for understanding the dynamics within the Green Lantern Corps and how personal experiences shape heroism. The passage about him being rescued by Simon Baz and B'dg also emphasizes the importance of camaraderie and support among heroes.

**Expert 3: Narrative Structure Specialist**
The narrative structure in these passages reveals a common trope in superhero stories: the hero's fall and rise. Guy Gardner's arrest and subsequent escape parallel the journey of many heroes who face setbacks. The mention of Superboy-Prime's imprisonment in a red Sun-Eater adds another layer, as it contrasts with Gardner's more personal struggles. This juxtaposition highlights different forms of imprisonment—physical versus psychological—and how they affect character arcs. 

**Expert 4: Thematic Critic**
Thematically, the passages explore the concept of imprisonment not just as a physical state but as a metaphor for the internal struggles faced by characters. Guy Gardner's experience in prison, where he confronts his own limitations and the betrayal by the Guardians, speaks to the larger theme of trust and betrayal within the superhero community. This theme resonates with the audience, as it reflects real-world issues of authority and rebellion.

**Points of Agreement:**
- All experts agree that imprisonment serves as a significant narrative device that contributes to character development and thematic depth.
- There is a consensus that Guy Gardner's character arc is central to understanding the dynamics within the Green Lantern Corps and the broader superhero narrative.

**Points of Disagreement:**
- While some experts emphasize the psychological aspects of imprisonment, others focus more on the physical confrontations and action sequences that arise from these situations.
- There is a divergence in how much weight should be given to the role of supporting characters like Simon Baz and B'dg in Gardner's journey, with some viewing them as crucial to his development and others seeing them as secondary.

**Cohesive Summary:**
The discussion reveals that the theme of imprisonment in superhero narratives, particularly through the lens of characters like Guy Gardner and Superboy-Prime, serves multiple purposes. It acts as a catalyst for character growth, a reflection of internal struggles, and a commentary on authority and rebellion. The interplay between physical and psychological imprisonment enriches the narrative, allowing for a deeper exploration of heroism and vulnerability. By synthesizing these perspectives, we gain a comprehensive understanding of how imprisonment shapes character arcs and thematic elements within the superhero genre, ultimately expanding our appreciation for the complexities of these narratives.

The interplay between physical and psychological imprisonment allows for a deeper exploration of heroism, vulnerability, and the complexities of character relationships. By synthesizing these perspectives, we gain a comprehensive understanding of how imprisonment shapes character arcs and thematic elements within the superhero genre.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
guardians of the galaxy blue guy in prison
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In the "Sinestro Corps War" storyline, Superboy-Prime and Cyborg Superman escape imprisonment when the Sinestro Corps attacks Oa, killing the guards on Prime Duty. Guy, along with fellow Green Lanterns Hal Jordan and John Stewart, are captured by Parallax during battle and brought to Qward. Guy and Stewart are then held prisoner by Lyssa Drak, who forces them to relive tragedies in their lives. Hal manages to defeat Lyssa and free Guy and John from their nightmare. In the skirmish following their escape, Parallax nearly breaks Gardner's neck. Upon returning to their universe, they defend Earth from the entire Sinestro Corps. After helping to free Kyle from Parallax's possession, Parallax is split into four pieces by former Guardians Ganthet and Sayd, and placed into the power batteries of Hal, John, Guy, and Kyle. Guy is infected by the Sinestro Corps' deadly alien virus named Despotellis, but cured by the Green Lantern Corps' own sentient smallpox virus, Leezle Pon.
', "Feeling depressed after a phone conversation with his family, during which his father dismisses superheroes as overly reliant on their powers, Guy attempts to spend the night fighting crime with only his natural skills. This backfires when he interrupts a police sting operation, culminating in him being arrested by his sister. While in prison, he is attacked by the Third Army, but is rescued by Green Lanterns Simon Baz and B'dg, who send the civilians to safety before crushing the Third Army and retreating to the Sea of Tranquility on the moon. Guy is angered when he discovers that the Guardians have turned against him and the Corps. Simon and B'dg dispatch him to the planet Oa. There, Guy reclaims his ring and joins Kilowog and the others reserve Corps members in their rebellion against the treacherous Guardians.
", 'Guy Gardner is the hot-headed member of the Green Lantern Corps. He is the third human to earn a Green Lantern ring. His antics caused a K'Vellian prisoner to go on a path of destructive rage, but thanks to Batman, the prisoner was stopped and he has Guy clean up the mess it made. He reappears in "The Eyes of Despero!" to help Batman overthrow dictator Despero. At first, he is extremely rude to Batman, constantly degrading him, but the last straw comes when he refuses to listen to Batman's plan; the Dark Knight punches him unconscious, and Gardner grudgingly gives his respect. He, Sinestro, and G'nort create a Batarmor for the job upon him requesting that he come. When he sees Sinestro attempting to blow up a rogue Mogo; they do battle, with Guy winning. Guy imprisoned Sinestro in his ring at the end of the episode. In fact, in this same episode he proves to have a much stronger conscience than he originally appeared to have. He also makes a brief cameo in "Mayhem of the Music Meister!". In "Death Race to Oblivion!", it is revealed that Guy has a fear of clowns when the Joker runs him off the road in a Mongul-sanctioned race for Earth's survival. In "Revenge of the Reach!" Guy Gardener is one of the Green Lanterns who try to get the "suit" off of Blue Beetle's back. He does not like the Blue Beetle in the beginning, but at the end they become friends. He is later seen fighting against the Starro invasion of Oa alongside Kilowog, Ultra the Multi-Alien, Captain Comet and Space Ranger before succumbing to the Star Conqueror.
', 'Communicating over the radio with Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau), a New York City Transit Authority police lieutenant, Blue demands a $1 million ransom to be delivered within one hour or he'll kill one hostage for every minute it is late. Green sneezes periodically, to which Garber always responds, "Gesundheit." Garber, his co-worker Lt. Rico Patrone (Jerry Stiller), and others cooperate while speculating about the hijackers' escape plan. Garber surmises that one hijacker must be a former motorman since they were able to drive the car down the tunnel.
', 'The Green Lantern Corps imprison Superboy-Prime inside a red Sun-Eater. The series ends with him carving an "S" into his chest with his bare hands and declaring that he has escaped from worse prisons than this.
', "It is revealed in the Guardians of the Galaxy series that Nagan is one of the inmates left behind in the Negative Zone's Prison 42. There, he is involved in a fight with Star-Lord, who is trying to stop Blastaar and his horde from invading Earth via the closed portal in the prison.
", 'Blair's leave on Akko Base in the Canewdon System is cut short, but he doesn't mind one bit: Zachary "Jazz" Colson, the traitor from "Wing Commander 2", has been sentenced to death, and Maverick will be escorting his prison ship. However, a distraction allows the Mandarins, a society of human traitors that Jazz belongs to, to hijack the "Bastille" and free Jazz. When he returns to the "Concordia", Blair discovers that a new squadron has arrived: the Wild Eagles, under command of Todd "Maniac" Marshall, flying the experimental "Morningstar" heavy fighters. Almost immediately the Morningstars show their problems: their jump drives don't work very well, forcing Blair to jump out and rescue an ejected pilot, Captain Maria "Minx" Grimaldi. She's very thankful for the rescue. Finally, while on patrol, Blair encounters a crippled Kilrathi "Dorkathi" transport, which surrenders. A Mandarin agent on board reveals that this freighter, the "Gamal Gan", was headed to Ayer's Rock, the Mandarins' home base. This is the first indication that the Kilrathi are actively aiding the Mandarins, though the player has known for a while: one of the game's opening scenes shows the Emperor ordering a Mandarin to capture a Morningstar using them.
', 'During the "Civil War II" storyline, Goliath is shown to be an inmate at the Cellar. Mad Thinker tries to recruit him during a massive prison break, but he declines. He later defeats the villains and saves several guards' lives. For his heroic actions, Goliath is released from the Cellar on parole.
', 'BULLET::::- "Guardians of the Galaxy" (2014) - Prisoner, cameo
', 'A year later, Superboy-Prime sits naked in his cell and is watched over by a special cadre of Green Lanterns, including Guy Gardner, when the Guardians of the Universe discuss whether they should question him.
']

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages. The focus will be on the relationships between characters, their actions, and the consequences of those actions, particularly in the context of imprisonment and escape.

### Extracted Content

1. **Guy Gardner's Imprisonment and Escape**:
   - Guy Gardner, a member of the Green Lantern Corps, is arrested after a failed crime-fighting attempt, which leads to his imprisonment. While in prison, he is attacked by the Third Army but is rescued by fellow Green Lanterns Simon Baz and B'dg. This incident illustrates the cause (his actions leading to arrest) and the effect (being attacked in prison and subsequently rescued).

2. **Conflict with the Guardians**:
   - Guy Gardner discovers that the Guardians of the Universe have turned against him and the Corps, leading to a rebellion. This reflects a cause-and-effect relationship where the Guardians' betrayal prompts Gardner and others to take action against them.

3. **Superboy-Prime's Imprisonment**:
   - Superboy-Prime is imprisoned inside a red Sun-Eater, and despite the harsh conditions, he declares he has escaped from worse prisons. This highlights the idea that the severity of imprisonment can influence a character's mindset and actions, suggesting that context matters in assessing a character's response to confinement.

4. **Nagan in the Negative Zone**:
   - Nagan is left behind in the Negative Zone's Prison 42, where he engages in a fight with Star-Lord. This scenario illustrates the dynamics of prison life and the potential for conflict even within a confined space, emphasizing the causal link between imprisonment and subsequent actions (fighting).

5. **Goliath's Parole**:
   - Goliath, an inmate at the Cellar, declines recruitment by Mad Thinker during a prison break and later performs heroic actions that lead to his release on parole. This demonstrates how actions taken during imprisonment can lead to different outcomes, such as redemption or further entrapment.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**:
   - The extracted content emphasizes the importance of understanding the causal relationships between actions and their consequences. For instance, Guy Gardner's decision to fight crime leads to his arrest, which in turn leads to his rescue. This chain of events can help the model learn to identify and predict outcomes based on initial actions.

2. **Character Motivations and Reactions**:
   - The passages provide insight into how characters react to their circumstances (e.g., Gardner's anger at the Guardians, Superboy-Prime's resilience). Understanding these motivations can enhance the model's ability to infer likely actions based on character traits and situational contexts.

3. **Dynamic Interactions**:
   - The interactions between characters in prison settings (e.g., fights, rescues) illustrate how confinement can lead to unexpected alliances or conflicts. This complexity can improve the model's ability to reason about social dynamics and predict interactions based on prior knowledge of character relationships.

4. **Contextual Influences**:
   - The varying contexts of imprisonment (e.g., the severity of conditions, the presence of allies or enemies) highlight the importance of context in causal reasoning. The model can learn to weigh different factors when assessing potential outcomes, leading to more nuanced logical inferences.

5. **Redemption and Change**:
   - The theme of redemption, as seen with Goliath's actions leading to parole, can inform the model about the potential for change in characters' trajectories. This understanding can enhance the model's ability to reason about character development and the implications of their choices over time.

By consolidating these insights, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to better understand and predict character behaviors and outcomes in complex narrative scenarios.

question_info.question: guardians of the galaxy blue guy in prison
passages:
In the "Sinestro Corps War" storyline, Superboy-Prime and Cyborg Superman escape imprisonment when the Sinestro Corps attacks Oa, killing the guards on Prime Duty. Guy, along with fellow Green Lanterns Hal Jordan and John Stewart, are captured by Parallax during battle and brought to Qward. Guy and Stewart are then held prisoner by Lyssa Drak, who forces them to relive tragedies in their lives. Hal manages to defeat Lyssa and free Guy and John from their nightmare. In the skirmish following their escape, Parallax nearly breaks Gardner's neck. Upon returning to their universe, they defend Earth from the entire Sinestro Corps. After helping to free Kyle from Parallax's possession, Parallax is split into four pieces by former Guardians Ganthet and Sayd, and placed into the power batteries of Hal, John, Guy, and Kyle. Guy is infected by the Sinestro Corps' deadly alien virus named Despotellis, but cured by the Green Lantern Corps' own sentient smallpox virus, Leezle Pon.
Feeling depressed after a phone conversation with his family, during which his father dismisses superheroes as overly reliant on their powers, Guy attempts to spend the night fighting crime with only his natural skills. This backfires when he interrupts a police sting operation, culminating in him being arrested by his sister. While in prison, he is attacked by the Third Army, but is rescued by Green Lanterns Simon Baz and B'dg, who send the civilians to safety before crushing the Third Army and retreating to the Sea of Tranquility on the moon. Guy is angered when he discovers that the Guardians have turned against him and the Corps. Simon and B'dg dispatch him to the planet Oa. There, Guy reclaims his ring and joins Kilowog and the others reserve Corps members in their rebellion against the treacherous Guardians.
Guy Gardner is the hot-headed member of the Green Lantern Corps. He is the third human to earn a Green Lantern ring. His antics caused a K'Vellian prisoner to go on a path of destructive rage, but thanks to Batman, the prisoner was stopped and he has Guy clean up the mess it made. He reappears in "The Eyes of Despero!" to help Batman overthrow dictator Despero. At first, he is extremely rude to Batman, constantly degrading him, but the last straw comes when he refuses to listen to Batman's plan; the Dark Knight punches him unconscious, and Gardner grudgingly gives his respect. He, Sinestro, and G'nort create a Batarmor for the job upon him requesting that he come. When he sees Sinestro attempting to blow up a rogue Mogo; they do battle, with Guy winning. Guy imprisoned Sinestro in his ring at the end of the episode. In fact, in this same episode he proves to have a much stronger conscience than he originally appeared to have. He also makes a brief cameo in "Mayhem of the Music Meister!". In "Death Race to Oblivion!", it is revealed that Guy has a fear of clowns when the Joker runs him off the road in a Mongul-sanctioned race for Earth's survival. In "Revenge of the Reach!" Guy Gardener is one of the Green Lanterns who try to get the "suit" off of Blue Beetle's back. He does not like the Blue Beetle in the beginning, but at the end they become friends. He is later seen fighting against the Starro invasion of Oa alongside Kilowog, Ultra the Multi-Alien, Captain Comet and Space Ranger before succumbing to the Star Conqueror.
Communicating over the radio with Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau), a New York City Transit Authority police lieutenant, Blue demands a $1 million ransom to be delivered within one hour or he'll kill one hostage for every minute it is late. Green sneezes periodically, to which Garber always responds, "Gesundheit." Garber, his co-worker Lt. Rico Patrone (Jerry Stiller), and others cooperate while speculating about the hijackers' escape plan. Garber surmises that one hijacker must be a former motorman since they were able to drive the car down the tunnel.
The Green Lantern Corps imprison Superboy-Prime inside a red Sun-Eater. The series ends with him carving an "S" into his chest with his bare hands and declaring that he has escaped from worse prisons than this.
It is revealed in the Guardians of the Galaxy series that Nagan is one of the inmates left behind in the Negative Zone's Prison 42. There, he is involved in a fight with Star-Lord, who is trying to stop Blastaar and his horde from invading Earth via the closed portal in the prison.
Blair's leave on Akko Base in the Canewdon System is cut short, but he doesn't mind one bit: Zachary "Jazz" Colson, the traitor from "Wing Commander 2", has been sentenced to death, and Maverick will be escorting his prison ship. However, a distraction allows the Mandarins, a society of human traitors that Jazz belongs to, to hijack the "Bastille" and free Jazz. When he returns to the "Concordia", Blair discovers that a new squadron has arrived: the Wild Eagles, under command of Todd "Maniac" Marshall, flying the experimental "Morningstar" heavy fighters. Almost immediately the Morningstars show their problems: their jump drives don't work very well, forcing Blair to jump out and rescue an ejected pilot, Captain Maria "Minx" Grimaldi. She's very thankful for the rescue. Finally, while on patrol, Blair encounters a crippled Kilrathi "Dorkathi" transport, which surrenders. A Mandarin agent on board reveals that this freighter, the "Gamal Gan", was headed to Ayer's Rock, the Mandarins' home base. This is the first indication that the Kilrathi are actively aiding the Mandarins, though the player has known for a while: one of the game's opening scenes shows the Emperor ordering a Mandarin to capture a Morningstar using them.
During the "Civil War II" storyline, Goliath is shown to be an inmate at the Cellar. Mad Thinker tries to recruit him during a massive prison break, but he declines. He later defeats the villains and saves several guards' lives. For his heroic actions, Goliath is released from the Cellar on parole.
BULLET::::- "Guardians of the Galaxy" (2014) - Prisoner, cameo
A year later, Superboy-Prime sits naked in his cell and is watched over by a special cadre of Green Lanterns, including Guy Gardner, when the Guardians of the Universe discuss whether they should question him.
